awd_titl_txt: NSF-BSF: Collaborative Research: Developmental genetics of host invasion initiated by fungal spores
awd_abstract_narration:
Fungi interact with their environments and with human life in various ways. Fungal adaptation to their environments has resulted in diverse fungal lifestyles. Just within the fungal class Sordariomycetes, there are examples of mutualistic symbionts living harmoniously with plants; pathogens that damage and kill plants or mammals; fungi that decompose organic matter; fungi that attack other fungi; zombie fungi that parasitize, manipulate, and kill insects. The life history of each of these fungi begins with a simple spore called a conidium. Conidia can be produced rapidly and in huge numbers, and provide the primary means for dispersal to new hosts. This research program will examine changes in gene expression among species during conidium germination and growth on different hosts. This will reveal the evolved features that enable spore germination and host colonization under different conditions to better understand fungus ecology and evolution. The diversity of fungi also renders them an exciting and tractable teaching platform; broader impacts include a fungal ecology education project in which students at Celentano Biotechnology, Health and Medical Magnet School 6th grade students collect, identify, and isolate fungi commonly found on plants and insects. 

This collaborative research will elucidate the genetic basis of sporulation and evolution of fungal parasitism in Sordariomycetes. This class of fungi contain members that have evolved the capability and specificity to attack plants, insects, fish, mammals, and fungi via in situ spore germination. Seven Sordariomycetes will be studied: two entomopathogens (Metarhizium anisopliae and Cordyceps militaris), a plant pathogen (Fusarium graminearum), a plant endophyte (Epichloe festucae), two mycoparasites (Tolypocladium ophioglossoides and Trichoderma asperellum), and the saprotrophic model Neurospora crassa (with endophytic capabilities). Asexual spores (conidia) of these fungi will be germinated to initiate colonies in medium and on host plants. Comparative genomics and transcriptomics will be performed on the resulting cultures. This will provide insights into their shared genetic programming and into the evolved basis of their divergent host preferences. Evolutionary ancestral expression inference will be used to identify genes responsible for pathogenicity. This approach will identify genes that have undergone recent shifts in gene expression during spore germination-in particular, shifts that occurred along the shared ancestral lineages where key traits (such as host specificity or pathogenic  morphogenesis) have evolved. Genes that are substantially upregulated, downregulated, or conserved in level of expression during the recent evolution of each of these seven species and their ancestors will be determined. These genes will be genetically perturbed and the resulting phenotypes will be investigated to determine their function in pathogenesis, potentially leading to new technologies for the control of fungal infections in diverse contexts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of our project was to reveal the genetic basis of conidial spore germination and the evolutionary genetic origins of fungal parasitism within the Sordariomycetes, a group of fungi that includes a wide range of ecologically and economically important species. To accomplish this goal, we applied evolutionary and comparative genomics to six fungi: the entomopathogens Metarhizium anisopliae and Cordyceps militaris, the plant pathogen Fusarium graminearum, the mycopathogens Tolypocladium ophioglossoides and Trichoderma asperelloides, and the model fungus Neurospora crassa. Our central aim was to understand the genetic differences that underlie how these fungi interact with and invade their respective hosts.

We collected transcriptomic data for all six species under standardized conditions, which enabled us to infer ancestral gene expression patterns at key evolutionary nodes. These insights were then used to guide gene knockout experiments, helping us to identify genes critical to the initiation of fungal growth and parasitic behavior. By combining transcriptomic data, phenotypic assays, and network reconstruction, we developed a systems biology framework that illuminated the regulatory mechanisms driving fungal adaptation to distinct ecological niches.

The findings of this research generated broad scientific interest and have been disseminated widely through peer-reviewed publications and conference presentations. In total, we published eleven papers in journals such as mBio, mSystems, PLOS Genetics, and Molecular Ecology, and presented our work at major conferences.

Beyond the laboratory, we have also worked to extend the broader impacts of this research through public outreach and education. We engaged K–12 students and the general public in the fascinating world of fungal biology and ecology, highlighting the roles of fungi in gardens and natural ecosystems. We partnered with educators, artists, and school administrators to develop an innovative art-and-science initiative that included classroom activities, teacher training, and student participation. This culminated in the creation of a mural celebrating evolutionary biology and fungal diversity, alongside the installation of a mushroom garden, completed in 2024.

Our research produced several significant outcomes. We generated over 300 gigabytes of transcriptomic data for conidial germination across the six fungal species, all of which have been deposited in the GEO database. A newly sequenced fungal genome has been made publicly available through GenBank, the JGI fungal genome portal, and the Fungal Database. We successfully established a CRISPR-based gene manipulation system in Cordyceps species, often referred to as “zombie fungi,” known for infecting insects. We also developed MRI-based methods to monitor fungal germination and growth in live rat models, providing a powerful new tool for studying host-pathogen interactions in vivo.

In addition, the project spurred new research collaborations and funding opportunities. We developed a collaborative research initiative with the U.S.–Israel Binational Science Foundation to investigate biocontrol strategies for fungal pathogens affecting trees. Internal support from Yale University enabled us to forge new partnerships with scientists in Brazil, Israel, and Europe to further advance the study and treatment of fungal diseases.

Training the next generation of scientists was a core component of this project. Rudy Diaz, a mycologist, received training in comparative genomics and transcriptomics and contributed significantly to the research. Postdoctoral researcher Yen-Wen Wang joined the Townsend Lab in July 2022 and played a key role in manuscript development and conference presentations. Meng Liu, another postdoctoral researcher, received training in transcriptomics and bioinformatics tool development, further strengthening our team’s computational capabilities. Two visiting scholars from Brazil, Victoria Bório and Emily Mesquita da Silva, were trained in research on tick-associated fungi and fungal pathogens. Undergraduate student Jennifer Wang received hands-on training in fungal culture and genomics, presented her findings at a major conference, and is now preparing two manuscripts based on her work.

Through this combination of cutting-edge research, scientific collaboration, and public engagement, our project advanced the intellectual understanding of fungal biology and promoted broader impacts in education.
